What measures are being taken by the Czech government to address negative attitudes towards immigrants and minority groups in the country?

The Czech government has taken various measures to address negative attitudes towards immigrants and minority groups in the country. Here are some examples:

1. Integration Policies - The Czech government has implemented various programs and policies aimed at addressing social and economic inequalities and assisting immigrants to integrate into Czech society. These policies include providing language classes, job training, and access to social services, among others.

2. Anti-Discrimination Legislation - The Czech Republic has introduced a range of legislation aimed at protecting minorities from discrimination, including the Anti-Discrimination Act of 2009, which prohibits discrimination based on race, religion, ethnicity, and sexual orientation.

3. Awareness Raising Campaigns - The government has also launched various awareness-raising campaigns to promote tolerance and combat hate speech and xenophobia, such as the "Migration for All" campaign, aimed at countering negative stereotypes of migrants and raising awareness of their contribution to Czech society.

4. Funding for NGOs - The Czech government provides funding to local NGOs to implement integration programs and projects aimed at reducing prejudice against minorities and promoting intercultural dialogue.

5. Partnership with International Organizations- The Czech Republic works in partnership with various international organizations such as the International Organization for Migration (IOM) and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to address the challenges facing immigrants and minorities, especially refugees.
